name: Bioinformatics
keyProblems: Managing and integrating massive biological datasets
Accurate prediction of protein function from sequence
Developing scalable algorithms for big data genomics
Handling data heterogeneity and noise in biological experiments
Predicting the impact of genetic variations on phenotype
Ensuring data privacy and security in healthcare genomics
timeline: 1965: Margaret Dayhoff publishes 'Atlas of Protein Sequence and Structure', foundational for protein databases.
1970: Paulien Hogeweg and Ben Hesper coin the term 'bioinformatics'.
1982: GenBank database is established, becoming a central repository for nucleotide sequences.
1985: BLAST algorithm is developed, revolutionizing sequence similarity searches.
1990: The Human Genome Project is officially launched, driving the need for massive data analysis.
1995: First bacterial genome (Haemophilus influenzae) sequenced, marking a major milestone in genomics.
2000: The draft sequence of the human genome is published, opening new avenues for research.
2007: Next-generation sequencing technologies become widely available, dramatically increasing data output.

subfields.name: Genomics
keyProblems: Identifying all functional elements in a genome
Linking genetic variation to disease susceptibility
Integrating multi-omics data for holistic understanding
timeline: 1990: Human Genome Project officially launched.
1995: First free-living organism (H. influenzae) genome sequenced.
2000: Draft human genome sequence published.
2003: Human Genome Project declared complete.
2005: Next-generation sequencing platforms begin to emerge.
advancements: Long-read sequencing technologies (PacBio, Oxford Nanopore) for complete assemblies
Single-cell genomics for cellular heterogeneity
CRISPR-Cas9 for precise genome editing
Population-scale sequencing initiatives
Cloud-based platforms for genomic data analysis

literature.name: The Human Genome Project: Initial Sequencing and Analysis of the Human Genome (Nature, 2001)
An Introduction to Bioinformatics Algorithms by Neil C. Jones and Pavel A. Pevzner
Genetics: From Genes to Genomes by Leland H. Hartwell et al.

subsubfields.name: Comparative Genomics
keyProblems: Accurate gene family delineation across species

subsubfields.name: Population Genomics
keyProblems: Distinguishing true genetic variants from sequencing errors
Inferring demographic history from genomic data
Identifying targets of recent positive selection
Handling complex population structures and admixture

subsubfields.name: Metagenomics
applications: Discovery of novel enzymes and antibiotics

subsubfields.name: Transcriptomics
keyProblems: Identifying true biological variation from technical noise

subsubfields.name: Epigenomics
keyProblems: Distinguishing cause and effect in epigenetic changes
Integrating epigenomic data with genomic data

subfields.name: Proteomics
keyProblems: Integration of proteomics with other omics data
Quantifying dynamic protein changes in cells
timeline: 1970s: Development of 2D gel electrophoresis for protein separation.
1980s: Advent of mass spectrometry for protein characterization.
1995: First full genome sequence of a bacterium, enabling proteomics studies.
2001: Completion of the Human Genome Project accelerates proteomics research.
2010s: Rise of quantitative proteomics techniques (e.g., TMT, SILAC).
advancements: Deep learning for protein structure prediction (AlphaFold)
Single-cell proteomics for cellular heterogeneity
High-throughput protein-protein interaction mapping
Improved mass spectrometry sensitivity and resolution
Proteogenomics for integrating genomic and proteomic data

literature.name: Proteomics: Technologies and Applications by Reiner Westermeier and Tomi Linke
Nature Methods Special Issue on Proteomics (various issues)
The Proteome: A New Frontier in Postgenomic Biology (Science, 2002)

subsubfields.name: Structural Proteomics
keyProblems: High-resolution structure determination for large complexes

subsubfields.name: Quantitative Proteomics
keyProblems: Distinguishing biological variation from technical noise
High dynamic range of protein concentrations

subsubfields.name: Interactomics
keyProblems: Distinguishing true interactions from false positives
Integrating different types of interaction data
applications: Identifying drug targets that disrupt protein complexes
Predicting protein function based on interaction partners

subsubfields.name: PTM Analysis (Post-Translational Modifications)
keyProblems: Understanding the dynamic interplay of multiple PTMs

subsubfields.name: Functional Proteomics
keyProblems: Predicting the exact biological role of a protein
Integrating functional data with other omics

subsubfields.name: Clinical Proteomics
keyProblems: Sample preparation challenges in clinical settings

subfields.name: Structural Bioinformatics
keyProblems: Accurate prediction of protein folding in vivo
Predicting binding affinities with high precision
Designing novel proteins with desired functions
Accounting for solvent effects in simulations
timeline: 1960s: Introduction of computational methods for protein modeling.
1970s: Development of molecular dynamics simulation techniques.
1990s: Emergence of homology modeling as a practical prediction method.
2000s: Growth of protein structure prediction challenges (CASP).
2020: AlphaFold achieves near-experimental accuracy in protein structure prediction.
advancements: Deep learning for highly accurate protein structure prediction
Improved force fields for molecular simulations
Enhanced sampling techniques for conformational space
Cloud computing for large-scale simulations
Integration with experimental structural biology methods

literature.name: Computational Protein Structure Prediction by J. Michael Word
Molecular Modeling and Simulation by Tamar Schlick
AlphaFold Protein Structure Database (EMBL-EBI)

subsubfields.name: Molecular Dynamics Simulations
keyProblems: Accurate representation of complex molecular systems

subsubfields.name: Protein Design
keyProblems: Ensuring stability and solubility of designed proteins

subsubfields.name: Ligand Binding Prediction
keyProblems: Accurate prediction of binding free energies
High computational cost of rigorous methods

subsubfields.name: RNA Structure Prediction
keyProblems: Predicting accurate tertiary structures for large RNAs
High computational complexity of prediction algorithms
Understanding the role of RNA modifications

subfields.name: Systems Biology
keyProblems: Incompleteness of biological knowledge for models
Scalability of models for whole-cell systems
applications: Drug target identification in metabolic pathways
timeline: Early 2000s: Emergence of systems biology as a distinct field.
2003: Publication of first genome-scale metabolic reconstructions.
2004: Launch of BioModels Database for sharing computational models.
2007: Development of the Systems Biology Markup Language (SBML).
2010s: Increased focus on multi-omics data integration and personalized models.
advancements: Development of whole-cell computational models
Machine learning for network inference
Integration of single-cell data into systems models
Increased use of cloud computing for simulations
Standardization of model formats and databases

literature.name: Systems Biology: A Textbook by Edda Klipp et al.
Introduction to Systems Biology: Design Principles of Biological Circuits by Uri Alon
The Handbook of Research on Systems Biology by Andreas Diehl

subsubfields.name: Network Reconstruction
keyProblems: Integrating multi-omics data for network assembly
applications: Identifying choke points in metabolic pathways

subsubfields.name: Omics Integration
keyProblems: Dealing with missing or incomplete data

subsubfields.name: Synthetic Biology Design
keyProblems: Dealing with biological noise and variability

subsubfields.name: Computational Neuroscience
keyProblems: Bridging different scales of brain organization
Understanding emergent properties of neural circuits
Handling massive neuroimaging and electrophysiological data

subsubfields.name: Pharmacogenomics
keyProblems: Identifying relevant genetic markers for drug response
Accounting for gene-gene and gene-environment interactions
Translating pharmacogenomic insights into clinical guidelines
applications: Optimizing drug therapy for individual patients

subfields.name: Bioinformatics Algorithms
keyProblems: Developing faster algorithms for large datasets
Handling noisy and incomplete biological data
Designing algorithms for novel data types (e.g., single-cell)
Ensuring statistical rigor in algorithmic outputs
Addressing computational complexity for NP-hard problems
applications: Drug target prediction via machine learning
timeline: 1970: Needleman-Wunsch algorithm for global sequence alignment developed.
1981: Smith-Waterman algorithm for local sequence alignment introduced.
1985: BLAST algorithm released, enabling rapid sequence similarity searches.
1990s: Development of Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) for sequence analysis.
2000s: Rise of machine learning methods in various bioinformatics problems.
2010s: Deep learning revolutionizes protein structure prediction and other areas.
advancements: Deep learning for enhanced pattern recognition in biological data
Parallel and distributed computing for large-scale data processing
Graph neural networks for biological network analysis
Quantum computing potential for complex biological problems
Explainable AI for biological insights

literature.name: An Introduction to Bioinformatics Algorithms by Neil C. Jones and Pavel A. Pevzner
Bioinformatics: Sequence and Genome Analysis by David W. Mount
Deep Learning for the Life Sciences by Bharath Ramsundar et al.

subsubfields.name: Sequence Alignment
keyProblems: Speeding up alignment for very large sequences

subsubfields.name: Phylogenetic Algorithms
keyProblems: Dealing with gene tree/species tree discordance

subsubfields.name: Machine Learning in Bioinformatics
keyProblems: Ensuring model generalization across different biological contexts

subsubfields.name: Genomic Assembly Algorithms
keyProblems: Scalability for large and complex genomes

subfields.name: Bioinformatics Databases & Resources
keyProblems: Managing exponential growth of biological data
Long-term archival and accessibility of data
applications: Protein sequence and structure databases (UniProt, PDB)
timeline: 1965: Margaret Dayhoff's 'Atlas of Protein Sequence and Structure' lays groundwork for protein databases.
1982: GenBank database established by NCBI.
1991: EMBL-EBI established as a European hub for bioinformatics.
1994: Protein Data Bank (PDB) becomes a public resource.
2000s: Growth of specialized 'omics' databases (e.g., GEO for gene expression).
advancements: Federated databases for seamless data access
Cloud-based data storage and analysis platforms
Semantic web technologies for data integration
Interactive visualization tools for complex biological data
Development of FAIR data principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable)

literature.name: Nucleic Acids Research Database Issue (annual special issue)
The Protein Data Bank (PDB): a historical perspective (Nature Structural & Molecular Biology, 2013)
Bioinformatics: From Genomes to Drugs by Thomas Lengauer et al.

subsubfields.name: Clinical and Disease Databases
keyProblems: Ensuring data quality from clinical sources

subfields.name: Bioinformatics in Healthcare
keyProblems: Integrating diverse clinical and genomic data
Ensuring data privacy and security (HIPAA compliance)
Translating research findings into clinical practice
applications: Predicting drug response and adverse effects
timeline: 2003: Completion of Human Genome Project sparks interest in personalized medicine.
2008: First direct-to-consumer genetic tests become available.
2012: Clinical sequencing becomes more common for rare disease diagnosis.
2015: Rise of precision oncology and targeted cancer therapies.
2020s: Integration of genomics into routine clinical practice, driven by advancements.
advancements: Whole-genome sequencing for routine clinical diagnostics
AI-driven interpretation of genomic variants
Liquid biopsy for cancer monitoring
Integration of multi-omics data in clinical decision support
Blockchain for secure health data sharing

literature.name: Clinical Bioinformatics: A Practical Guide by Rong Chen and Atul J. Butte
The Future of Personalized Medicine: Genetic Prediction and Prevention by Ronald M. Evans
Nature Medicine Special Issue on Precision Medicine (various issues)

subsubfields.name: Clinical Genomics
keyProblems: Distinguishing causative variants from benign ones
Data sharing and privacy in clinical settings

subsubfields.name: Translational Bioinformatics
keyProblems: Reproducibility of research findings in clinical settings
Integration of diverse data sources (EHR, omics)

subsubfields.name: Bioinformatics in Drug Discovery
coreConcepts: ADMET prediction (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion, toxicity)
keyProblems: High false-positive rates in virtual screening
Optimizing drug candidates for multiple properties

subsubfields.name: Health Informatics
keyProblems: Ensuring data quality and completeness in EHRs
Protecting patient privacy and data security

advancements: Near-accurate protein structure prediction by deep learning (AlphaFold)
Routinized whole-genome sequencing for clinical applications
Single-cell omics technologies enabling granular biological insights
Development of comprehensive multi-omics data integration platforms
Advances in liquid biopsy for non-invasive disease detection
CRISPR-Cas9 accelerating functional genomics studies
Cloud-based bioinformatics pipelines for large-scale data analysis
AI-driven drug discovery accelerating lead identification

Current Protocols in Bioinformatics (Wiley)
PLOS Computational Biology (Journal)
Bioinformatics (Oxford Academic Journal)
